_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

An uneducated ordinary person regards form as "This is mine, I am this, this is my self."
That form of theirs decays and perishes
Sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise
They regard feeling, perception, choices, consciousness as "This is mine, I am this, this is my self."
That consciousness of theirs decays and perishes
Sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise
How not grasping leads to freedom from a: An educated noble disciple regards form as "This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self."
That form of theirs decays and perishes
Sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress do not arise
They regard feeling, perception, choices, consciousness as "This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self."
That consciousness of theirs decays and perishes
Sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress do not arise
